comments.body: Superseded by #178.

bibdata.title: New export type: all records with OCLC numbers

comments.body:
I finally ran and compared Esmé's implementations. 

The Ruby version is way too slow, it takes about ~7 minutes per file, that translates to 13+ hours for all 100 files. 

The Java implementation is incredibly fast, it takes about 10 seconds per file. 

The Go implementation is somewhere in between, it takes 35 seconds per file.

I forked Esmé's repo and put it under https://github.com/pulibrary/pod_scripts and standardized the scripts to run each of the implementation so that it's easier to compare and contrast.

Update circleci and inchci badges in readme

comments.body: I added a new coveralls token for the bibdata repo in circleci.

bibdata.title: Migrate availability response status fields to Alma

comments.body:
This item is in a Preservation process:

MMS Id: 99116973763506421
Holding ID: 22245146270006421
Item ID: 23245146260006421
~~Process type: Pres~~
Process type: WORK_ORDER_DEPARTMENT / In Process
Work Order Type: Pres / At Preservation

It looks like the `process_type` (Process Type for acquisition) values available for our installation are are:

```
ACQ,                        "Acquisition"
CLAIM_RETURNED_LOAN,        "Claimed Returned"
HOLDSHELF,                  "Hold Shelf"
ILL,                        "Resource Sharing Request"
LOAN,                       "Loan"
LOST_ILL,                   "Lost Resource Sharing Item"
LOST_LOAN,                  "Lost"
LOST_LOAN_AND_PAID,         "Lost and paid"
MISSING,                    "Missing"
TECHNICAL,                  "Technical - Migration"
REQUESTED,                  "Requested"
TRANSIT,                    "Transit"
TRANSIT_TO_REMOTE_STORAGE,  "In Transit to Remote Storage"
WORK_ORDER_DEPARTMENT,      "In Process"
```

Fetched via https://api-na.hosted.exlibrisgroup.com/almaws/v1/conf/code-tables/PROCESSTYPE?apikey=enter-your-key
Yeah I'm still not really sure how process_type is related here. I think what we want is work_order_type. But we may need these, too, at some point?

I _think_ process_types include things that aren't on work orders. For example, HOLDSHELF is just a status that gets toggled without being associated with a work order. Work orders all have a process_type of WORK_ORDER_DEPARTMENT.

bibdata.title: Refactor cjk_notes to use more enumerable methods

dpul.title: I'd like to be able to save a default sort order for when you search or are in a Browse Category

comments.body:
@hackartisan and @tpendragon . perhaps an easier way forward, that would empower users to create order themselves on pages via a widget (the item row widget, specifically).  If we can constrain proportions of the thumbnail to help standardize the size, I have a feeling that may be an easier and more sustainable route.  We could also workshop the size of the thumbnail, thereby also being able to similarly address and close #858.  

There is also the option of getting the item embed widget to function properly. But I would love your thoughts on this.
That might make sense for the use case of a guided exhibit experience -- there wouldn't be too many items. Is the idea that it might be preferred to showcase them in that way?

@hackartisan Yup! As luck would have it This idea was a direct result of a recent use case. An individual from Mudd is creating an online companion to a physical exhibit that was in Mudd previously. This is how they would like to display the items

dpul.title: Can we make all DPUL exhibit texts (within the widgets on pages and in browse categories) searchable within a particular DPUL exhibit?

comments.body: Yes, only records are indexed. None of the page content of the site is indexed. The results page lists digital object records. This would be a significant new feature, possibly involving the creation of a new index depending on how design discussions went.
Good to know. Since it has been asked for by folks at another institution and DPUL is continuously seeing more use, I thought it would be good to ask, just in case.  Thanks!

comments.body: Closing this ticket — the object was a MVW where the parent rights statement was changed, but the volumes still had the old rights statement.

figgy.title: As a figgy ephemera project owner, I would like to download a CSV of all folders in my project, including those that are boxless

comments.body:
I think you can fix this by changing reports_controller.rb#8 to
``` ruby
@resources = @ephemera_project.boxes.map(&:folders).flatten + @ephemera_project.folders
```

figgy.title: Expand fields included in ephemera metadata export

comments.body: See also  https://github.com/pulibrary/figgy/issues/4431

I think you could include the folders this way:
``` ruby
@resources = @ephemera_project.boxes.map(&:folders).flatten + @ephemera_project.folders
```
Note the change to request, this should output a TSV file, not a flat text file.

pulfalight.title: Components with 2 boxes associated not creating separate transactions
Move findingaids.princeton.edu to the load balancer
in aspace2pulfa, make sure bioghist goes in the right place
we need a way to get structured access restrictions out of ASpace
PULFA 2.0 should be servable from https://pulfa.princeton.edu
Send one Aeon transaction per box.
Biographical/historical notes do not always appear in finding aids

comments.body: Hm, it seems likely this is a timing issue. It may be that because indexing new resources every hour aspace hasn't finished indexing the agent when we pull the EAD. I'm not sure if we'd need to index less often (nightly again, probably) to fix or if there's some other way to handle this.
Ah. Could indexing perhaps happen somewhere in between every hour and nightly?

If it's solely a timing issue then probably not - there's always the chance that during the day our scheduled time would coincide with when the record was edited recently. I can look into seeing if we can schedule a "double-check index job" or something, or if maybe we can track changes for agents and see if when they change we can reindex attached EADs.
Thanks, Trey.
It looks like there's just something wrong with our indexing, re-indexing that record didn't add the bioghist note. That's good news - probably easier to fix. I'll look into it soon.

@faithc 

Oh wow, this is pretty bad UX in aspace. I'm sure it has a reason, but yeah.

Okay, so it's a user entry issue that I also would have done. The agent for C1667 has a bioghist note which is published, but the sub note (which has the actual content), is NOT published. If you edit the agent and check that box it should reindex with the bioghist.

![Screen Shot 2021-03-09 at 2 56 44 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2806645/110549963-b5c02000-80e7-11eb-90aa-fb6a4f0586b5.png)
Oh wow, that's ridiculous...Thanks for investigating, Trey!
